claim: If unlimited substitutions had been permitted in Poland's domestic league matches in 2010/2011, the average goals scored by home teams would have been lower.
extra_info: average home team goal = AVG(home_team_goal)= SUM(home_team_goal) / COUNT(DISTINCT Match.id) WHERE name = 'Poland' and season = '2010/2011';
reasoning: The claim is a counterfactual hypothetical about what would happen under different substitution rules. The database contains only actual match results (home_team_goal, away_team_goal) and has no data about substitutions, substitution limits, or the impact of rule changes on scoring. There is no way to verify or refute whether unlimited substitutions would have lowered the average home team goals in Poland's 2010/2011 season.

    country_id       INTEGER

The average home team goals for Poland 2010/2011 is about 1.504. 

Now the claim is about what would happen "if unlimited substitutions had been permitted." This is a counterfactual/hypothetical claim. The database contains match results from actual games played under standard rules (typically 3 substitutions). There's no data about what would happen under unlimited substitutions.

The database doesn't contain any information about substitutions made in matches, nor any data about hypothetical scenarios with different substitution rules. This is a counterfactual claim that cannot be verified or refuted with the data available.

content.text: The claim is about a hypothetical scenario: "If unlimited substitutions had been permitted" — asserting that the average home team goals would have been lower. The database shows actual match results for Poland 2010/2011, but let me check if there's any substitution data:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claude-code-claimdb/test_dbs/european_football_2.sqlite" "SELECT goal FROM Match JOIN Country ON Match.country_id = Country.id WHERE Country.name = 'Poland' AND Match.season = '2010/2011' AND goal IS NOT NULL LIMIT 1;"

);

The database has no substitution data. The goal column is empty for Poland 2010/2011 matches. The Team_Attributes table has tactical attributes but nothing about substitutions.

The claim is about a counterfactual hypothetical: what would happen if unlimited substitutions were allowed. The database only records actual match results under actual rules. There is no data in the database to determine whether unlimited substitutions would increase or decrease home team goals.

This is clearly NOT ENOUGH INFO.

content.text:
The database contains no substitution data whatsoever. The claim makes a counterfactual assertion about what **would have happened** if a different rule (unlimited substitutions) had been in place. The database only records actual match results under the actual rules that were in effect. There is no information in any table about substitutions made, substitution limits, or any hypothetical impact of rule changes on scoring.

While we can compute the actual average home team goals for Poland 2010/2011 (≈1.504), the database provides no basis to determine whether unlimited substitutions would have made that average higher, lower, or the same.

The database contains only actual match results (home_team_goal, away_team_goal) and has no data about substitutions, substitution limits, or the impact of rule changes on scoring. There is no way to verify or refute whether unlimited substitutions would have lowered the average home team goals in Poland's 2010/2011 season."}
